history.content:
Took EE117 last semester with Yablonovich. It was a small class, only ~20, and I think a good number of those were grad students. Overall, I think it was a worthwhile class -- gave me more insight to EM physics and antennas. I also took 16B concurrently and even though they say 16B is a pre-req, I really don't think it needs to be. The most you use from 16B is RLC circuits, impedance, and phasors, which they cover within the first few weeks. In general, I would say it has a pretty light load. There were weekly problem sets that took less than 3-4 hours usually. The concepts and math can get quite hard, but his exams were pretty fair. If you go to lecture (or watch, since he records) and read the textbook, then you can pretty easily keep up. There was one midterm and the final was worth 60%. Usually he follows the textbook, but pay attention when he teaches some concepts that are not in the book because he definitely tests on those (i.e. vector potential).

The mini-labs are very quick (usually 1-2 hours) and mostly just consists of taking measurements, and yes there are only 6. He doesn't begin lab until about a month in, and you have a few extra weeks at the end to make up any ones you missed.

I want to take EE117 during Spring 2019 and wanted to ask for insights about the course in general /workload, hw, labs, class participation, etc./.

I will be coming with physics7b and ee16a background, and will take ee16b concurrently. 

Also, syllabus from previous years states that mini-labs start from mid-Feb and there are only 6 of them, does it mean that for the weeks when there is no lab, we just skip that lab section. 

Thanks.
history.subject: Insights about EE117
